description.text:
Various camera mounts and clamps for the Contour HD1080P and similar digital video camera. I've got a couple of these and wanted a better range of mounting options for the car, motorbike, mountain bike etc.
They all use a common sliding mount that fits very well with my cameras.
I'll add more parts as I need them - probably a handlebar clamp next...

Print it all out in PLA with 0.35mm nozzle, 3 layers, 3 perimeters, 25% infill and 90 degree fill angle.
Holes are correct off the printer for 4mm machine screws and 1/4" Whitworth camera mount thread (or whatever that thread is). The two halves of the tipod base glue together with a camera-type nut in the middle. Make sure the nut is held tightly - if it rattles add some packing above the nut before you glue the top half in as it needs to be held to the bottom of the tripod mount base to work correctly. The bike mount suits 1" or 25.4mm handlebars and uses the same top section as the tripod mount. Takes 2 x 4mm machine screws and nuts. Mount1s.STL is the tilt top for either the tripod of the bike mounts.
Tripod Base2.STL is the base for the tripod with Mount1S.STL
Bike mount.STL uses Mount1S.STL as well for the handlebar mount etc.
Mount2.STL is the fixed universal mount with a captive camera-type nut in the base.

author: mrobbins

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

Here's a set of Girih tiles, as well as a box to hold them in. Based on these:
Lasercut Girih tiles
Which were popularly used in Islamic architecture. I find these more pleasant and fun to play with than Penrose tiles, as you're less constrained and don't have to worry about breaking edge conditions. They also look lovely when tiling a surface as the knotwork stands out while the joins are quite subtle.

Choose a suitable wood or plastic for your box and tiles, and cut. I used the 3 line pattern to avoid having to paint segments directly, but you can delete the middle line and use a mask like sticky paper instead. Cut the file using high power low speed to get the edges free, and low power high speed for the lines. You can then peel back part of the mask and paint the area if you wish, removing the rest of the mask after paint is dry. On our 50W laser I used 10mm/sec & 45% power for the cut, and 50mm/sec & 15% power for the scoring. The concept of using the over/under design was inspired from here:
http://itsacleanmachine.blogspot.com.au/2012/07/acrylic-girih-tiles.html

Made with K3Dsurf, meshlab, and blender.  
5/29/14--added the supported model that I printed. The support structure used Meshmixer and manually added columns... 150% scale, triple the file size, not manifold, and not really "reccommended"....
10/7/16--printed another in red.  This time I used Simplify3D manually-placed support, was pretty happy with the results.

description.text:
I didn't like the original Samsung dock for my current phone so I decided to make my own.   
Some of the features I think it should have are that it must be fully useable also in the dock. So I made some openings from the back to the front to have the sound come from the front, this seems to work even better then expected. I also wanted to use the original charger cord so I made it possible to secure the plug inside the dock.   
If you have the same phone and print it out, let me know what you think, I'd like to get your feedback.

Printing this with 0.5mm thickness for the bottom, shell and top should be enough. I use a infill of 30% to get a nice strong part, but it will work with 20% infill as well. I'm using a fan to get the overhangs right.

description.text: UPDATE 1/26: Added the frets in with nearly the right spacing. Still working out a few last kinks before I lazzzor this.

Inspired by Bre's talk at ROFLThing in NYC yesterday, I finally hit upon the thing that has been in my head that I wanted to make real... my very own Flying V Rockin' Ukulele. The idea of being able to create a set of open-source instruments available to make on-demand is pretty exciting.
This hasn't been actually lazzzored yet, but I plan to try it this week at craft night. I am looking for feedback on material to use, design isses, tips and any other ideas you might have.

Rather than doing a standard curved-sided instrument, the Flying V design allows for straight edges all around. There are three neck pieces, which will be layered on top of each other for increased thickness.
I gained basic guidance from visual images of commercial versions of this instrument found on the web, but all the vector work was done freehand in Inkscape. 
I also still need to figure out where to put the frets!

description.text:
One-piece printable drawbot/polargraph gondola intended to replace the CD-based, pop-riveted lash-up I had been using up to now. Contains mounting points for a bulldog clip (fix into place with two M3 bolts), micro servo for pen lift and M10x75 bolt & 3 nuts for weighting. Beaded cord will fix through the pen holder with no additional fixings.  
Printed at the Bristol Hackspace on a RepRap Mendel.

Print the gondola - warning: overhangs! You may find that the first few layers of the edge don't adhere very well near the bottom, this wasn't serious on my print and just required a bit of sanding  
Drill two holes in the back of a bulldog clip - the drill bit will certainly wander unless you centre punch it. Once the holes are drilled mark the required holes on the bracket and drill through the plastic, I didn't include holes in the bracket because I found it hard to drill the bulldog clip accurately. I used M3 bolts to fasten the bulldog clip in place, this takes up a bit of space inside the bulldog clip but helps to centre the pen.  
Drill out the pilot holes for the servo mounting to the size you need, then fix the servo screws.  
Thread the beaded cord through the holes in the bracket under the bulldog clip, the arrangement is shown in the picture of the assembled part but you generally need to have the cord come out of the upper hole, pass through inside the bracket between the holes, out of the lower one again and underneath before being mirrored on the other side.  
NOTES: the hole for the pen lift arm of the servo isn't quite in the right place on my version, I'll alter it on the next iteration but it seems to work and could easily be filed down if it binds too much. The overhang around the edge is a pain to print, I'll probably alter it for the next one. It's hard to access the pilot holes for the servo mount when drilling them out, I might move one of them to the other side or change to a different mount principle. The base plate is probably strong enough but it feels a bit thin, I might bump the thickness up a bit. As it stands it is functional but not very 'polished'.  
NOTES (after first use): the bulldog clip can interfere with the cord, this can cause quite a lot of lack of precision so I found it best to thread the cord through the centre of the clip arms. The servo position seems to work well, I get clean lifts with no odd movements at the start or end of lines. The width of the support (around 15mm between the ends of the cord) needs to be considered in any driver code, as does the height of the pen above the cord attachment (also around 15mm). Overall: works well, still needs a few changes.

This is a low-cost rotary adapter for my laser engraver, made from 4mm plywood and scrap parts from other projects that I had lying around. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MU9nrsXyCf8 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nF63Rftva8A

Cut the parts from 4mm plywood.   
I used 4 old skateboard bearings, a NEMA14 with an EasyDriver module and to make the wheels less slippery I put pieces from a latex glove on them.   
For your controller settings: The EasyDriver is set to 8 microsteps/step per default and with this setting the rotary needs 5120 pulses (640 steps) per revolution.

description.text:
Pcb and eagle files for hmeyer [http://www.thingiverse.com/hmeyer] cheap magnetic endstop [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24189]
It's designed to fit Mendel Prusa's standard endstop holders so it should work with most reprap printable holders.

In Eagle, display only bottom, pads and dimension layers. File->Print select "black" option, print it with a laser printer on magazine's paper (the best one are the free advertising magazines and catalogues, doesn't matter if they are full of ink :) then lay the printed circuit on a copper clad, fix it with tape, set your flatiron to max temp and apply pressure for 10-15 mins till it starts to smell burnt. Let it cool down completely, remove the paper, the toner rapresenting the circuit should now be on the copper. Etch it, cut accordingly to dimension layer, drill holes, place components, solder them, now the endstop is ready. Set a piece of neodimium as endstop trigger, wire it to your electronic and enjoy!

comments.text: Hi - one trick I've found for Toner Transfer is to set the holes down to about 8 mils (0.2032 mm) as then the resulting small hole seems just right for a drilling "center punch" locating hole, lots easier than trying to get the drill to not wander when drilling :) (The ideal hole is just large enough to always etch through, and just small enough so that the drill knows exactly where "center" is) :) HTH

No assembly necessary. Just print and play Seej. This model interlocks with Seej Columns: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29411 Extended bloxen interlock with other extended bloxen, but are too wide to interlock with mundane bloxen. --=] Copypasta Seej Verbiage [=-- Seej is a tabletop wargame based around 3D printing. Check out http://s33j.net for rules and more information. If you're not playing Seej yet, you'll need the Seej starter set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24013 You can also search Thingiverse for Things with the seej tag. Other Thingiversians are busily expanding the library of Seej engines and fortifications. Be sure to check Zheng3.com for updates. title: Magnetic coupled ROV thruster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
ROV/Submarine thruster with permanent magnet coupler.
Used 12 rare-earth magnets 10x20x2.9mm, 540-type DC motor, stainless M3 screws and nuts, stainless or brass rod, brass or fiberglass bushes, silicone O-rings (41x1.5 x2, 44x1.5 x2), silicone tube (for wire insulation)
Test result: thrust 2.5N at 12V2.5A, not so perfect results.

comments.text:
HI, is it possible
to number the parts and provide the simple assembly topology drawing based on
that numbers Sir? I did not understand how it must be assembled at the front
side, mostly magnetic inner coupling part…where it must be, in what part? Sorry.
Please help to understand you and your nice design.
comments.author: MrArrow1961

comments.text:
Sorry, no time for this staff for now, ill try to describe it here.
Coupling consists of two main parts - inner and outer, both with six holes for magnets, inner part (smaller) just put on motor shaft (with two nuts an two threaded pins), outer part longer than magnet length, so, use six magnet stoppers in the holes (after magnets) to align top surface. Then put into round sliders three paddles, then cover it with round cap.
Also you need brass rod and two fiberglass bushes (i made them from glued bunch of old PCB), that bushes glued into holes of outer rotor, brass rod screwed into cover (wich covers inner rotor)
P.S. - prop side is back side, not front :-)))

The latest macs don't have a firewire 400 connection and so a 400 to 800 cable is needed to connect an iSight.  This doodad holds the iSight with an attached 400 cable and has a bolt hole at the base for a standard tripod mounting screw.

The included scad has variables to adjust the x and y axis to match the firewire plug.  No support needed to print, and the threaded portion for the tripod mounting is from the threads.scad so no need for a nut.  The threads might be a bit tight but are great once it's been threaded once.
Update: Fixed the .scad with the correct module enabled for rendering.

This is a simple bracket designed to fit in the rectangular hole in the back panel of the Heathkit HW-101 transceiver.  You can use this to add accessories to the radio  (like the pot illustrated) without drilling any new holes.  Openscad source code is included so you can change the hole to whatever size you need.  The stl here has a 1/4" hole.
Just print it.  It's quick & easy - no support required.  The segment with the raised part fits through the rectangular hole, the other piece goes inside, and the pot holds them tightly together.

remixed_from.author: Bror
remixed_from.title: Parametric dial gauge holder for Replicator

title: YADIH - Yet Another Dial Indicator Holder For Replicator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There are a number of different dial indicators holders out there for your Replicator when leveling your platform. 
However, dial indicators and magnets come in different sizes.
This design is inspired and pays homage to the other holders out there, but is fully parametric to fit your needs.
You can change magnet size, dial indicator holder size, wide or narrow holder and also if you want a 2 or 4 magnets holder.

If you have small 12mm diameter x 1 mm thick magnets and a 9.5mm diameter collar dial indicator and want a beefy holder, then just print the stl.
Otherwise download the scad, change the settings, print and push in or glue the magnets in place.   I printed at 50% fill for strength.

comments.text: Hi, jetty, thanks for posting this thing. I will give it a try. Since you mentioned the need to download and customize locally, have you considered making this a customizer friendly thing? This will allow people to customize the magnet size without having to use openscad. Since your source is a .scad file, you are 99% there. Info here http://customizer.makerbot.com/docs
comments.author: zapta

comments.text: A suggestion to help with the issue with holding the magnets -- make the holes that the magnets mount through come from the top side with an internal shoulder.  This is so that when the dial indicator holder is on the machine, the magnets are pulling against a plastic shoulder.  Then it does not matter how much glue you put on the back -- it will not interfere with operations.  Also, if I design a variant I will likely print 4 plugs and permanently install them in place over the magnets to keep them in place.
comments.author: ebo

comments.text: Great idea for attachment using magnets. The best holder that I printed so far. I printed also an adapter to fit my smaller diameter dial indicator. But I have trouble to attach the magnets. I have 10 and 12 mm x 1 mm magnets and when I print it the diameter appears to be 11.6mm. I cannot insert 12mm and it is too wide for 10mm. My magnets are very strong and I have trouble to hold them with glue to the holder. Maybe I will reprint it with slots to insert the magnets from the internal side and to close the open ends with glue gun.
comments.author: AGG

comments.text: This is the second best thing I have ever printed. The best thing was the thing printed immediately after I'd used this thing to properly level my bed for the first time!!!
comments.author: ThePuzzleGeek

comments.text: This is by far the best. Thank you!
comments.author: AwesomeA

comments.text:
very cool!
I think this is one of the best examples of scad project.
In my case, I added following codes instead of configuring "dialGaugeCollarDiameter" for fixing dial indicator.
Because it is difficult to make inner diameter of circle exactly for me.
comments.author: cc777

author: jetty

title: Toy rocket, with USB lithium battery charger and LEDs

description.text:
This is a toy rocket, in 3 parts. I wanted also to add some lights, so I found a "generic" USB lithium battery charger on ebay (see photo). This keeps a battery charged while a switch turns on/off the LEDs. To add the switch I drilled a hole on the side of the rocket; didnt have a switch at the time.  
Note: The mid-section of the rocket, has 4 partial spheres sticking out. These spheres each have a 5mm hole (inside the rocket) for adding the LEDs.  
Also, there is a USB slot, for the battery charger (under the rocket), and slots inside the base for retaining the battery charger PCB

Mechanical drawing done on FreeCad (happy to send source files).  
Print it in stages. The USB charger pops into the base (there is a usb slot at the bottom, inside the main "engine". I also added slots to retain the USB charger.  
Will publish a wiring schematic fairly soon

title: Deer head scaled and chopped up - STL Files

description.text:
I've been dying to print the chopped up gigantic deer head but didn't want to deal with all the .step files, so I converted all of them to STLs. Enjoy! I've also added a spreadsheet of all the file names. I'm using it to track my progress so I don't print more copies of any part than I need to and so I remember my settings if they got changed for whatever reason. Addition
I've created a plug that you can glue in and use to mount the deer head flush against a wall. It isn't the most snug fit, but since you're gluing everything anyways, it should be secure. The file has the uninspired name of plug.stl. Once I have my own printed, I'll change out the picture. Huge props to Sharka for putting it online in the first place.

remixed_from.author: javialamo
remixed_from.title: Perry the Platypus the Inaction Figure

description.text:
A model based on Perry the Platypus from the Disney's Phineas & Ferb series.
I scaled the model down to approximately 98mm x 36mm x 24mm (LWH) when assembled. Also added 5mm x 6.5mm pegs to the legs, with a corresponding 5.2mm hole in the body section. If you know how to widen the holes, I recommend you widen them to about 5.5mm so that you won't need to drill it out.

I used 10% fill, 0.27mm layer height, HBP temp 120C, nozzle temp 220C, 1 shell. If you will be printing this entire model in one color, just print PTP_All_Parts_v1.stl. Otherwise if you have a dual-extruding Replicator, download the Perry The Platypus v1 - STL Parts for Dual Extrusion Merging.zip file. For the body, tail, legs and beak section, merge the two STL files named PTP_Appendages.stl and PTP_Body_Section.stl and print. Then to make the two colored eyes, merge together PTP_Eye_Scleras.stl and PTP_Eye_Pupils.stl and print. To attach the beak, tail and eyes use some glue, instant or otherwise. This is my first project and the fit for the legs wasn't perfect, so I had to carve out a little bit of the body to insert the pegs.

This will be re-uploaded to another site once a suitible site is found. I do not believe that I, or the original author (in the case of my derived works) appreciates giving up all rights to own our own designs. Once A suitible location is found, or a temporary one is located, A note will be posted here. Have fun!
http://randmsystems.com/stuff/public.php?service=files&t=97ab3dd20a903c17c8625ef382e78404 This is my modified template for printing masonry style bloxen for Seej. This does more then print 6 at once, and less. These models are slightly different then the stock-bloxen and are made to correct what I saw as minor problems with the model. Fixes:
The merlons have been narrowed slightly, this prevents the bloxen from snapping together vertically, which made a fairly difficult to break barrier.
The holes have been moved slightly as well, allowing the bloxen to stack at 90 degree angles without a overly tight fit.
Some of the bloxen had their merlons removed to allow a flat-top and more asthetic appearence (Also some of us like to put the flags up there! Bonus points for hitting a flag without hitting the bloxen...) Regretably, I have no pictures at this time. But it does turn out pretty cool =)

There are large gaps between the bloxen, this is actually quite deliberate. This model was designed to twin-print 12 bloxen at once using the both-extruders code found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24195 Which it does very well, with default replicator settings I have not had any stringing or issues in the prints at all! =)

MakerBot Defender
CodeName - MD-B12 My Makerbot CNC aka \"DemonDust\" is the Queen ant, and a Queen ant produces the soldiers on the \"front line\". The Makerbot Defender is designed and built to protect as a soldier, just as in nature a soldier ant protects a well structured colony all working as one unstoppable force. UPDATED PARTS - 5/10/2010
-Makerbot_Robot_B_LeftElbow_v2
-Makerbot_Robot_B_LeftShoulderBolt_v2
-Makerbot_Robot_B_RightArmJointConnector_v3
-Makerbot_Robot_B_LeftHandJointConnector_v2 These upgraded parts solve loose joint issues and strengthens moving parts Features : This version is made from ABS plastic built on a heated platform. Version #1 tank treads are hard to move, but moveable. Upgrades are being designed and will soon follow The mounted cannon is for defense purposes only. Launching non-lethal smoke prejectiles to create smoke cover to confuse and slow invaders Infrared camera is mount on the shoulder helping to watch over the Queen for temperture accuracy Every soldier in nature is equipped with a strong pair of claws. These arms can move over 180 degrees front to back with claws that can be opened and held in any position. Upgrades are being designed for the next
version of arms/claws Upgrades : One of the best pre-designed ideas for the MakerBot Defender,it is upgradeable. The mounted cannon and Infrared camera just slide right out of the main body panel. Making it possible to design anything and replace existing features. Scale: Rough measurements
7\"(wide) x 8.5\"(deep) x 7\"(tall)
Instruction Pages can be found at the bottom of this page and on the left side! If there are an questions feel free to email me.

description.text: This is a holder for a stack of magnets. Once sealed it becomes a (relatively) child-safe object that will open these magnetic child-safe cabinet locks: http://www.amazon.com/Safety-1st-Magnetic-Locking-Complete/dp/B004GCJMLG/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1347039672&sr=8-1&keywords=magnetic+cabinet+locks This solves the problem of losing the key that comes with the locks, having a key that is a color that displeases you, or of paying too much for the replacement/extra key: http://www.amazon.com/Safety-1st-Magnetic-Locking-System/dp/B004FI7USI/ref=pd_bxgy_ba_text_y Note that you may be able to use one large magnet rather than a stack of four. I just had a ton of that kind of magnet on hand.

• Consider your child's safety:
    a. magnets can pose an intestinal perforation danger to children if ingested.
    b. Anything of a certain size can pose a choking danger to children if not quite successfully ingested.
    • To be absolutely safe, do not allow any magnets in your home.
    To be not quite as safe, get professionally assembled magnet-device-assemblies.
    To live in the DIY future, print this yourself, assemble carefully, drop test the thing, and work hard to keep it out of your child's grasp. This should be hard to choke on, but it should also never be allowed come to that point.

  • Acquire materials:
    a. four rare earth (neodymium etc.) magnets, 0.5" diameter x 0.1" thick
    b. ABS filament (you can of course use PLA, but be sure to super-carefully adhere lid as it is the key to keeping this from being extra hazardous to your child)

  • Print part:
    a. it should print with the lid next to it.
    b. print 100% fill, no extra shells; it still won't take that long to print.

  • Stack Magnets: Let them join up in a stack (0.5" diameter, 0.4" tall)

  • Confirm Polarity: the magnets should face a certain direction to open the latches.

  • Assemble:
    a. insert magnet stack in key body
    b. install lid over magnets:
    c. wipe edges of lid with acetone
    d. insert lid in hole
    e. use a q-tip or similar to liberally apply acetone around the top of the seam... just in case.

  • Drop test: be sure the lid won't come off, or the handle won't break off and be a choking hazard, etc. It may help to paint the outside with acetone to increase inter-layer strength.

  • Use... Carefully! Please heed all warnings at the beginning, and all warnings I forgot, and your common sense.

description.text: Ditch the flimsy paper "wrapper" of your Hobby King Cellmeter 6 and protect it AND your drone with this! The case is appropriately sized (not much bigger then the original) and protects the alarm cutoff push button from being hit accidentally. See instructions for more.

To install, remove the "wrapper" from your Cellmeter. There might be a free-standing crystal oscillator in there that could stick to the tape inside the wrapper, be careful.  
You may need to depress the push button in order to make the PCB slide in the hardcase.   
Cram in a piece of double sided foam tape for added security, or put tape around the edges of the PCB for a snug fit.

description.text: 100% printable scale armor. No metal rings necessary. I reverse-engineered scale armor through research so that plastic plates and rings could be printed. I am currently creating a scale armor tunic for an individual study in my studio art major at UMW. My blog on the project: http://awatkins.umwblogs.org/category/methods/3d-printing/ If you're curious about scale armor, Wikipedia has an informative article http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale_armour

Each scale needs two rings to link together. I find it useful to multiply my build platform http://www.makerbot.com/tutorials/skeinforgemultiply/ and print two scales and four rings alternately. I set the pair of scales to print at 5 infill at accelerated speeds on the Replicator and the rings to print at 50 infill at non-accelerated speeds. In this configuration each print takes about 20 minutes. A note about the rings: on the two printers I've used, the ring comes out pretty tight, I like this, it keeps the scales together well; however, it does require popping the ring's spiral out while it's warm and bendy. If it's too tough to do by hand, it's easy to sneak a small pair of scissors in there to loosen the stuck area. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1dKD2n-kvVo The Ring Lord scale maille tutorial is where I learned how it should look. I have a post on the design process on my independent study blog: http://awatkins.umwblogs.org/methods/positive-and-negative-z/

author: awatkins

comments.text: I printed mine in grey PLA and it came out great.  This tool is a huge time saver for me.  Thanks for posting this.
comments.author: Jimbotron

comments.text: On my recently bought Duplicator 4S the "inside shoulders" made it too narrow to fit over the hotends. The thick wires connected on the sides are crimped into metal shoes that stick more out on my machine.
comments.author: arnljot

comments.text: Perfect file, thanks for the upload.  Worked awesome on my duplicator 4.
comments.author: Munckis

comments.text: I made this for my AVATAR IV and it works great. WANHAO, AVATAR and FLASHFORGE (and others) all use the same extruder/hot end and they all have the same problem. One side is always out of alignment. One issue I have is lossening a nozzle makes it, well, loose! To solve this issue I used some PTFE high temp plumbers tape. It's a little too wide so I cut it with a razor blade. Makes the nozzle less wobbly after loosening to bring into alignment.
comments.author: billkaroly

comments.text: You can adjust the height of the nozzles without loosening them.  Just move the heat tube up or down in the aluminum block.  They're held in place with grub screws.
comments.author: billkaroly

comments.text: Can you explain this better?
comments.author: arbello

comments.text: I already know that my right extruder is not leveled compared to the left one but... how do i fix that?
comments.author: FTcuber

comments.text: i had this problem with my brand new duplicator 4s, i made a shim out of layers of foil cut and folded to fit exactly under the lower side, then punctured the foil so i could get the screw through... nice and level now
comments.author: FTcuber

comments.text:
Printed with PLA and it came out great. Printed on the side I know the nozzle is lower so it didn't drag or catch.
I will test it out later today and see how it works. Wanted to wain until after I install my new low friction extruder nozzles from Performance 3-d. I already installed the Aluminum Arm Stiffeners and they really seem to take a lot of the play out.
Thanks this should be very helpful!
comments.author: JMA321

This is a 3D printed spool stand for the printrbot. It is used to hold the plastic spool in the side of the printer to provide a smooth unrolling action. You need 4 roller bearings and 2 bolts and nuts (optional).

This object is a derivative from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29594. Is an spool stand intended to be printed instead of laser cutted (for those who do not have a laser cutter). You need 4 roller bearings (608) and M3 bolts and nuts (optional). There are 2 different pieces, base and arm. You need to print 1 base and 2 arms that fits perfectly. Be careful with the dimensions. I design this pieces for my plastic spool (120mm width), but maybe it'is not correct for yours. By the way, I provide the parametric scad file for changing the parameters, such as width, height, bolt diameter, etc. In the base the word "DOWN" was written to put this side down :-P. I've imported the letters from this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15198.

The stl model is derived from serial CT data of a fossil mammal-like reptile. For the last 30 years I have  developed 3D computer and physical models  for education and research. The makerbot makes this now possible on a very wide scale by the distribution of the stl files derived from volume (voxel) data and serial digitised contours. I have modelled human and animal brains, fish head anatomy, turtles, fossil birds, teeth etc. Using a makerbot would make this technology accessible. 
makezine.com/go/makerbot

The example was chosen to show how the system works. It involves going from voxel data files to surface triangles, available in amy free 3D imaging packages (such as 3Dview). Stl files produced will need fixing and stl repair programs are widely available. It is within the capacity of anyone with a makerbot to make anything

title: mk7 extruder - plastic replacement part - should be milled with 3-axis cnc-router

description.text:
This is a file for replacing the mk7 plastic extruder feed housing. This design feature material-guidance up to the metal-rod-to-hot-end and not like the original ones only up to the rotating metal-screwlike-wheel (open below). You can see it on the photos. The newer MK8 have this feature anyway.
I milled them out of pom and they worked really good until I replaced them recently with all the mk8 easy spring mechanism improvements.
Should work with flex material - because of material-guidance.

This is only for documentation, design is from summer 2013. I rather would suggest anybody to get a "MK8 kit" from Makerbot (where even the old and bigger MK7 gear fits; about sizes of gears: http://reprap.org/wiki/Drive-gear) so to have a spring loaded drive that makes it more easy to change filament.
In Thingiverse you find also the latest "MK8" remixes with closed bottom for flex-material, and as said even the "old" MK7-diameter gears fit on most of them or after adjusting the geometry.

Original MK7 here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11734

MK8 here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53125

For milling in POM. 2-sided job for a 3-axis cnc.
Rough with a 3mm-Shaft.
(Re-rough/Pre-finish with 3mm-Ballhead.)
Finish with 1mm-Ballhead.

author: UserMaker

description.text: This is my very own spool holder made exclusively for the wonderful M3D printer which is currently on Kickstarter. My friend received his and here it is next to it!!! See the campaign here: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/m3d/the-micro-the-first-truly-consumer-3d-printer#project_faq_86355 I am so excited to get this little printer, I had to create this as an homage to the design and also to have something while I wait for the little wonder to arrive at my doorstep in December. I 3D printed it at work on a 3D touch machine. It used about 400 grams of PLA I have tried to match the design as much as I could by studying the images from the M3D website http://themicro3d.com/ I modelled it using ArchiCAD (I am an Architect and an Architectural Illustrator) ArchiCAD is in my opinion the worlds best Architectural BIM software which has STL output capabilities from version 17. www.graphisoft.com I hope you enjoy printing it as much as i enjoyed making it. I have received information as to the rough sizing the filament that will come with the little machine from the makers!!! And i will be creating another version to hopefully hold 3 spools at once side by side. I will have it done this week hopefully. The sad news is that I will not be getting one now ;-(...... The wife said not to the expenditure and to keep on using the office 3D printer.....So so sad. Anyways if you have suggestions as to what could be made next i am more than happy to make them. I gave my test piece at work to a work colleage who I convince to get one so it went to a happy home.

author: maxemo2001

description.text:
The original looks like a great case. Only had a few issues that were corrected:
  • One half was NOT normalized (it was floating above the print surface) FIXED
  • No indents for the case closures to latch the case closed ADDED.
  • Was only provided combined and too big for some printers- needed to be separate to print on smaller printers. FIXED.
  • Needed to be a little stronger - too easy to break. FIXED
  • Needed a break-out spot for a GPIO cable if used. ADDED
    • All files are consistent now. And I think I finally have it appropriately cleaned up, strengthened and printable after 4/25/14 rev!! This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/e3YECt67i29

Print the two separate files- they have been run through nettfab to clean the files up..  
Does not need support- use it if you want.

This is a lens holder for the FLIR Ex cameras, it holds a 20mm lens snugly and fits snugly into the camera.  I made this because the other one available is quite bulky and a little temperamental to get the angle to print clean.  This one prints in about 4 minutes by itself but I recommend printing at least 3 at a time to allow cooling.  
These are setup for a .35mm nozzle which will produce 2 perimeters through the entire print.  I have infill set to 100% as well as concentric infill but it may not be needed at this point because I trimmed it down to force 2 perimeters.  
This one is small enough that the camera is almost fully unobstructed except for a little fuzziness at the bottom.

Update 2014-0610: This is the updated and finished version of the one piece printed eggbot. Did some changes around the right side idle shaft, to have room for the egg holder cup. This will house a normal size egg or a golf ball. Mine works mechanically just fine. I'm still fighting with the software. I'm using two 625-2RS bearings, pressed into the housing's right side barrel. The egg holder suction cups are from the well known suction cup toy darts. I used M4 screw and nut to secure the pen-upright to the stepper motor shaft. You've got to make sure that the shaft/screw that holds the pen arm upright and pen arms together will not add wobble. I recommend using a smooth screw, with threads only at the end. I'm using a HEXTRONIK HXT 500 servo. The upright arm will house a Hitec HS-55 servo too, but for some reason it was wired backwards so I swapped it for the hextronik.
The arduino mounts directly to the frame. You can run the stepper motor wires within the printed frame.

description.text:
This cute little bunny will be the perfect Easter gift for your little one that values a challenge. This isn't just a toy that will be opened, played with and forgotten. It is a puzzle that enchants the owner just as the Easter bunny does for all of our little ones. This is an original and unique gift that will hop into the heart of your puzzle-solver this Easter weekend.   
The pink bunny is scaled up 150% and the white bunny was printed at 100% scale.

Print out all STL files. I suggest printing at 25% or more fill. Quantities follow each file that is over 1. Construction directions can be found by opening the 3D Puzzle Bunny Manual.pdf  file.  
A hobby knife and sanding paper may be needed for all parts to fit. Glue together with super glue or hot glue if you would like a permanent Easter bunny.  
Enjoy!

title: QU-BD One Up / Two Up X-axis Endstop Mount Spacer

description.text: X-axis endstop mount spacer bracket to be used with MacAttak's X_Switch_and_ZAdjuster-_for_MacAttakextruder-_v1.stl mount and the original extruder.

Reworked the X_Switch_and_ZAdjuster-_for_MacAttakextruder-_v1.scad file to create a new mount to move the endstop -Y (to clear the X-drive belt) and +X (to clear the stepper motor and end of travel).
Note that the Sainsmart endstops won't engage against a flat surface reliably. I added a M3 cap head screw to the side of the extruder body with some M3 washers as spacers to engage the switch.

author: caterpie999

title: Yosemite's Royal Arch and Washington Column

description.text: This 3d topo shows the north wall of Yosemite Valley from Serenity Crack (5.10b) to North Dome Gully. It includes Washington Column. It is useful for visualizing the standard descent from Washington Column. In 3d the "Death Slabs" section is very easy to see and it is obvious how and why to avoid it. While this model is no substitute for a map and good beta, it presents the cliffs in a form which is much easier to grasp ;-) You can see my tutorial video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bzwybr65I9o I made it from a LIDAR dataset available on http://opentopo.sdsc.edu/. The data was collected as part of a study of rockfall in Yosemite. Try not to think about that as you climb the cliff.

comments.text: Very cool man, thanks for this tutorial. I was looking to do something exactly like this. Definitely a process, but the level of detail achieved surpasses any other more simplistic "geo-printing" process.

Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner. Trespasser belongs to Travis Beacham and Guilliermo Del Toro's Pacific Rim.

remixed_from.title: Vitamin Free RepRapPro Huxley 120mm Fan Mounts

title: Customizable Vitamin Free Huxley Fan Mounts

description.text:
Clip on fan mounts for additional cooling for your RepRapPro Huxley -   
Customizable to fit that weird sized fan that you've been saving just in case...

Measure your fan, and the separation between the M6 Threaded rods on your Huxley Frame Triangles (the distance between the inner surfaces of the rods, not the center-to-center distance).  
Print out 4 copies per fan you want to hold, clip in to place, and wire up.  
Inspired by indieflow's fan mounts, and the fact I only had an 80mm fan in my Mad Inventing box!  
Happy cooling!

author: jeremygold

description.text:
A fully customizable coupler, based on my previous one : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:286339
I hope you'll enjoy it! Edit: I updated the y position to enforce it a bit, and changed the nut default size to 6.25mm, because 5.5 was too tight.

Well, you just have to define your axis diameters. The widest diameter should be on top (unless you like adding support material for nothing ;).  
The nut diameter is the maximum diameter of the nut (distance between the edges, not between the faces).  
I think it's all you need to know, the rest is pretty straightforward!

title: Magnetic, detachable key ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I need an RFID badge, which I attached to my keys, to open the door to my company's garage. This means I have to turn of my engine, open the door and restart my engine every morning to get into the garage. To solve this, I designed this magnetic detachable key ring. Now I can easily detach my badge from my keys.

Print both parts, then glue a disc magnet on top of part A and one inside part B.
It's designed for 2mm thick disc magnets of 6mm diameter, like these http://www.supermagnete.ch/eng/S-06-02-N?img=1
You can also find them on eBay http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_odkw=neodymium+magnets+6x2&_osacat=0&_from=R40&_trksid=p2045573.m570.l1313.TR0.TRC0.H0.Xneodymium+magnets+6x2mm&_nkw=neodymium+magnets+6x2mm&_sacat=0
To glue them in I used epoxy, but good CA-glue (superglue) may work too.

description.text:

Than there is a support for the flanged bronze nut.

description.text: This is meant to cover the hole where a ceiling fan used to go, but allow 3 wires to come out for 3 pendant lamps nearby.

title: Stake for Outdoor Solar Mini Path Lights

description.text:
These are replacement stakes for Outdoor Solar Mini Path Lights. My father has had a few of the stakes brake on him, so I thought it would be a great use of my new printer. I made two designs for the stake, first is the actual design that I reverse engineered and second is one that I modified. I printed the modified design and tried two different layouts for printing (see pictures). I created the parts from scratch in AutoDesk Inventor, so I posted the .ipt files along with the .stl files for both versions.
  • Original Design File: Stake- for Solar Mini Path Light (ORIG Design).stl
    • Original Design File: Stake- for Solar Mini Path Light (New Design).stl
    • Note: Another stake that is similar but for a different purpose is by MNinventor - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15286

I printed the parts on an Afinia UP! PP3DP printer.  I have only had it for a couple weeks, so I am not the best at setup yet.  I tried printing it in two different orientations; still not sure which one is the best.  I still need to give the parts to my Dad for testing.  I used the normal speed setting and only slightly changed the default settings.

A modular hat for wearable technology prototyping. Modular Belt is part of Openwear Wearable Prototypes Felt Edition.
Learn More: http://openwear.org/blog/?p=1832 REMEMBER: It contains an add-on to hold a Lilypad CHECK THESE PICs FOR INSPIRATION
http://www.flickr.com/photos/openwear_cc/sets/72157630820574680/

• Open the file and adjust the length according to the circumference of your head
  • Feed the lasercutter with 3mm felt of your desired color
  • Sew it!

Print your own thumb screw for Gopro.
Match the Gopro accessories. The design is for 30/35/40/50 mm long M5 screw with hexagonal head.
The first screw insert need to be done with power (or just tighten it into an open nut). Notice that the 30 mm screw is too short for use as the camera screw (the 35 mm version might be as well, I haven't printed it yet), the 40 and 50 mm are fine there.
The 40mm version is in the size of the original screw

Just print the part that match your screw size.
Put the M5 screw in the part. And enjoy :-)

comments.text: Downloaded, printed, buying screws in an hour. at roughly $15 to buy and $0.3 to make I'd be stupid not to (calculated cost of printing, as well as buying bolt and nut and making 20). Back with a "make" later.

description.text: These spinners were designed by Odie_wan. I mirrored the forward cone and base and ran some repair scripts on the orignals so they would be accepted by slicr3. They fit the 5x3 props of my Rabid Models 28" P38 Lightning. All the credit goes to Odie!

These were printed in ABS with solid infill and 0.178mm layer thickness. Raft and full support were both used. After printing, I polished them with 600 grit sandpaper and painted them with a Posca paint-pen (water-based paint). They can be seen painted and spinning on the model in this video.

author: mikespray

title: Modular Dungeon Walls
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a collection of various scale dungeon parts.  The "grid" is a 30mm grid because I like my walls to straddle the grid "lines".  So 4mm thick walls and 26mm squares gives a 30mm grid.
I was inspired by the various dungeon wall models here and thought I could improve on the designs to make them more modular and flexible and increasing the things they can do.
I'd like to make multi-level models.  With this design, walls can connect at any ordinate angle and should mesh well.  No need for corner, tee, cross walls.  (Although I will most likely make some of those for convenience.)
I will be adding more models as I finish them.
One improvement that I will most likely make is to add a small pocket to the bottoms of the floor pieces and possibly the tops and bottoms of the walls.  This pocket would be sized to fit a small magnet.  The magnets would help the floor tiles hold to a metal surface (since they aren't very heavy) and the magnets might also allow you to stack walls vertically.
I've printed most of these parts and they work well now.  I've made some changes to some parts to improve the printability.  The hinge parts no longer have holes in them.  You will need to add holes post-process.  I've found that paper clips work great for hinge pins!

There are two parts that have a top and bot(tom).  Glue these together.  They were separated so that they could be 3D printed without support.
The door hinges will require some sort of pin.  The holes are around 1mm diameter.  I am planning on using sewing pins (the kind with flat heads that look like mini nails) and cutting them off to the right height.
No more base parts required.  And now the walls will stand up on their own until you place the floor tiles over their supports to lock them into place.

comments.text: I like the idea of spacing between tiles to make room for features. It's a good one. I did something similar with the tile set I uploaded, but only with exterior walls. I didn't think to extend it between the actual grid. Something for me to think about.
comments.author: Telvin_3d

comments.text: Okay, so the post and holes are probably not going to work with the makerbot.  I have the hardest time making small holes!  I think stability will also be an issue here as you pointed out.  I'm thinking of a new way to make the wall and hopefully it will remove the need for the base piece altogether as well as fix the stability issue.
comments.author: Telvin_3d

comments.text: Stability might be an issue until the top pieces are placed.  Although I designed the parts to interlock a bit so they should support each other.  Once the cap pieces are placed the whole thing will be very stable.  (As long as you don't tip it upside down)  :)
comments.author: Telvin_3d

comments.text: I did mine in 2x2 sections due to the Makerbot constraints. The 10cm build platform means that you could barely do a (roughly) 4" object but that doesn't allow for any outside details or variance. 3" (7-8cm) objects would be quite doable and I considered trying to think up a system based around 3x3 tiles, but it doesn't work out very cleanly for things like corridors and intersections. So 2x2 it was.
comments.author: TheRooster
